comments.message:
Not sure we need the bindings.

From what I understand, only the types are really needed.

I'm not entirely sure either, but when I do take them out I get errors trying to mkapp. Something like this:

** ERROR:
Client interface 'le_data' of component 'writeConfigTree' in executable 'writeConfigTree' is unsatisfied. It must either be declared an external (inter-app) required interface (in an "extern:" section in the .adef) or be bound to a server side interface (in the "bindings:" section of the .adef).


and same thing with le_mdc, le_avc. Maybe I am missing something here..?

is: '%s'

Best to have quotes, just in case.
You do not need to include that, as it's automatically included through interfaces.h

comments.message:
I see what you meant for that.
I think we might be able to get away with some env variables defined in the sdef
All static functions need to be CamelCase.
Should also be a const char * pathToDataPtr.
Should be NULL by default, and not a string.
Use the le_avdata_DataType_t enum instead of strings. Strings are slower and are not as comfortable to handle in C.
Provide a default statement, even if empty.
All that can be replaced by a loop over the structure defined above.
There is actually a macro for that called NUM_ARRAY_MEMBERS in le_basics.h, it would be best to use it.
I will add dataType for LE_AVDATA_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT, that is the only one missing I believe
Same, and not sure why this is not done in the same loop.
I was going to do it in the same loop but I decided to make the creation of resource and registering handlers separate for readability like the sample app assetData. I will add them together now.
Change has been successfully merged by Bertrand Roussel

commits.commitMessage:
Fixed timing issue with pollingtimer and SIGTERM

Resolves: FARM-806
Change-Id: I2619918d26739485cfed93ac5a1407f667b32868
commits.subject: Fixed timing issue with pollingtimer and SIGTERM

comments.message: I needed a way to access the timer to stop it in the sigeventhandler function. Let me know if there is a better way, but for now this works perfect.
No that seems good, just init PollingTimer = NULL;
You're registering the timer after the SigChildEventHandler (which should actually be called SigTermEventHandler ...), so potentially if the app dies, PollingTimer is not init so you might seg fault.

commits.commitMessage:
[App] TrafficLight to monitor jenkins job statuses

Resolves: FARM-712
Change-Id: I66a8e286fae4a2548f57d43d78e4ecb0e165eacf
commits.subject: [App] TrafficLight to monitor jenkins job statuses

comments.message: Actually that would be Sierra Wireless Inc.
Would be good to add a picture of what this looks like here.
Do you mean a physical picture I take with my phone?

trailing whitespaces

List should be more with a space after the -, so:
- a
- b

- Legato 16.10.3
Add the png within the repository, not as an external link
Name of the file could be better (TrafficLight-Schematics.png ?)
To be placed in a subdirectory (doc/ ?)

gpioGreen / gpioOrange / gpioRed might be best.
That way on another platform we can just reroute through a #if #else in this adef
cf comments regarding names of GPIO

By default do not put a private resource.
You could put the travis status from legato-af ( cf https://travis-ci.org/legatoproject/legato-af )

ContentExpected

Overall code should respect Legato coding standards: http://legato.io/legato-docs/latest/ccodingStdsMain.html
Should be const, your function shouldn't modify the buffer.

No the idea is to look for a keyword in the buffer.
The application shouldn't know about SUCCESS or FAILURE or anything else. It should just have a way to set, through the config tree, that if there is 'SUCCESS' in the page then it means green state, else if there is 'FAILURE' it means red state, ...

This app is meant for Jenkins while the requirement is that it should be generic.
You're setting status in the test part, which is usually considered as bad practice.
You need to add some documentation for each functions.

Each of your checks is setting the light, which doesn't work so well.
I would like the checks to return a return code (pass/warning/fail?) and the lights are set at the end to reflect the worst state (minReturn(exitCode, contentCheck, ...)
For instance:
- exitCode PASS
- contentCheck WARNING
=> WARNING => Orange

- exitCode FAIL
- contentCheck PASS
=> FAIL => Red

Try to keep config tree entries as lowerCamelCase
So no CamelCase in the config tree for keys.
Lots of dead/commented out code to be removed.

It would be good to split things into 2 components:
- 1 that takes care of checking stuff, and provides an API with a HANDLER to be notified in case of state change.
- 1 that registers to the check API and takes care of updating the lights in case of state change.
That could be in another patch though, I'm okay to keep the architecture as this as a first implementation.

Also I'm not seeing the le_sig_SigBlock + le_sig handler to handle the SIGTERM and turn off the lights when the application is terminated
It at the beginning of the line?
It would be good to have a buffer here, line Url[512] or something like that.

There should a ' *' even if the line has no comment

So:

 * ffsdfasd
 *
 * sdfasdf

As explained in my previous comments, this function should not be calling SetLightState. It should not know about lights. It should just compute a monitoring state which is either PASS, WARNING or FAIL.

Then, at the end of the exit code checking / content checking, you translate the monitoring state into a light state.

Seems like it would be best to have that declared in this function rather than globally.
Overall Global variables is to avoid.

overall we don't do malloc in Legato.
It's either statically allocated or through memory pools (cf le_mem.h)
Seems like you should pass a pointer here
buffer is not a pointer, this is right. ptrBuffer is not a pointer to buffer. I have changed the variable name so that it is more understandable in my next patch
There should be only one call to GetResult (which should actually be called CheckJenkinsResults because its really just meant for Jenkins.

The description of your functions should not be about what the implementation does, but more about what this is realizing for your app.

Look at few functions in like le_sms.c or mem.c

LE_DEBUG?

Otherwise the 'seconds' variable is badly named.
Should be PollingIntervalSec or something like that.
Should be one function like GpioDeinit

Changing this means I have to change the source code file name unless you want me to rename the source code to main.c from trafficlight.c.
Also, from the sample apps it seems like they all do this instead of main.c so maybe this way is more consistent?
I will fix my tw in the code right now for next patch :)

At the moment only GetUrl(); function uses this but I cannot put it in the function. This is because the poolRef will be initialized every polling cycle and the system doesn't seem like that (It stops the app).

I am trying to find a solution currently to get my way around this, but at the moment it works only when declared once.
No that's fine that pool can stay global.
I will change this next patch to STATE_FAIL, STATE_WARNING, STATE_PASS

I wonder if that is necessary.
By default I think it takes the tree for the application.
So Txn("/") should be the same as Txn("trafficLight:/").
Can you check if that's the case?
Yes it is the case, I have changed it now.

The 'config' command has to stay absolute.
Also remove the $ at the beginning, and there should be an empty comment line after the first line.
